ygData.subject: Re: [neat] Dominant and Recessive genes
ygData.msgSnippet: Hi, In Nature (tm) recessive and dominant genes come about not by turning one of other of them off, but because one of them does something and the other does

From: Ian Badcoe <ian_badcoe@...>
Subject: Re: [neat] Dominant and Recessive genes
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=7192225; y=n0H1ey0H7QvjHDnXg2HqFRWif_KmlSvp4gN2OmDCnaIi2O1enA
X-Yahoo-Profile: ian_badcoe

Hi,
	In Nature (tm) recessive and dominant genes come about not by 
turning one of other of them off, but because one of them does 
something and the other does not.  The one that doesn't do it is 
recessive.  Thus if you have two recessives, neither works, so you 
get the recessive phenotype.  But if either gene is dominant, it 
works, and you get the dominant phenotype.

	In some cases you can use a lot of some gene's product, and the 
double dominant phenotype is different from the dominant/recessive 
heterozygote.  And in other cases, the alternative alleles are not as 
simple as "works" and "don't work" and you get more complex genetics.

	Examples are sickle-cell anemia (where two defective haemoglobin 
genes give you _much_ stronger symptoms) and the ABO blood groups 
(where A and B are both "dominant" and the AB blood group is where 
you have one of each...)

	Dunno whether this affects your musing...

	Ian
In 15 minutes everybody will be in the future.
